Compressed Sensing Matrices from Fourier Matrices

Guangwu Xu and Zhiqiang Xu Department of EE & CS, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Milwaukee, WI 53211, USA; e-mail: gxu4uwm@uwm.edu. Research supported in part by the National 973 Project of China (No. 2013CB834205).Inst. Comp. Math., Academy of Mathematics and Systems Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; e-mail: xuzq@lsec.cc.ac.cn. Zhiqiang Xu was supported by NSFC grant 11171336 and by the Funds for Creative Research Groups of China (Grant No. 11021101).
Abstract

The class of Fourier matrices is of special importance in compressed sensing (CS). This paper concerns deterministic construction of compressed sensing matrices from Fourier matrices. By using Katz‚Äô character sum estimation, we are able to design a deterministic procedure to select rows from a Fourier matrix to form a good compressed sensing matrix for sparse recovery. The sparsity bound in our construction is similar to that of binary CS matrices constructed by DeVore which greatly improves previous results for CS matrices from Fourier matrices. Our approach also provides more flexibilities in terms of the dimension of CS matrices. As a consequence, our construction yields an approximately mutually unbiased bases from Fourier matrices which is of particular interest to quantum information theory. This paper also contains a useful improvement to Katz‚Äô character sum estimation for quadratic extensions, with an elementary and transparent proof. Some numerical examples are included.

Keywords: ‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT minimization, sparse recovery, mutual incoherence, compressed sensing matrices, deterministic construction, approximately mutually unbiased bases.

1 Introduction

In many practical situations the data of concern is sparse under suitable representations. Many problems turn to be computationally amenable under the sparsity assumption. As a notable example, it is now well understood that the ‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT minimization method provides an effective way for reconstructing sparse signals in a variety of settings.

One of the most commonly used frameworks for the compressed sensing matrices Œ¶Œ¶\Phiroman_Œ¶ is the restricted isometry property (RIP) which was introduced by Cand√®s and Tao [8]. RIP has been used in the randomized construction of CS matrices (see for example [1, 8, 10]). Another well-known framework in compressed sensing is the mutual incoherence property (MIP) of Donoho and Huo [14]. Several deterministic constructions of CS matrices are based on MIP, e.g., [12, 24, 37].

The main focus of this paper is on the deterministic construction of CS matrices. It is noted that there is a significant gap between the bound (5) and the (asymptotically optimal) bound (3). The allowed range of sparsity for the case of a deterministic partial Fourier matrices is far smaller than that of the binary case. Constructing partial Fourier matrices deterministically that work for a larger sparsity range of signals is certainly of particular interest.

The aim of this paper is to construct a partial Fourier matrix which is a CS matrix, through a deterministic procedure. Based on a celebrated character sum estimation of Katz [20], we are able to obtain a bound for the sparsity kùëòkitalic_k in the case of partial Fourier matrices that is similar to (3). More precisely, we have shown that if q=paùëûsuperscriptùëùùëéq=p^{a}italic_q = italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a prime power and n>1ùëõ1n>1italic_n > 1, setting N=qn‚àí1ùëÅsuperscriptùëûùëõ1N=q^{n}-1italic_N = italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 or N=qn‚àí1pb‚àí1=pa‚Å¢n‚àí1pb‚àí1ùëÅsuperscriptùëûùëõ1superscriptùëùùëè1superscriptùëùùëéùëõ1superscriptùëùùëè1N=\frac{q^{n}-1}{p^{b}-1}=\frac{p^{an}-1}{p^{b}-1}italic_N = divide start_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG(b‚à£aconditionalùëèùëéb\mid aitalic_b ‚à£ italic_a is required for this case), then there is a deterministic process to select m=qùëöùëûm=qitalic_m = italic_q rows from the Fourier matrix ‚Ñ±(N)superscript‚Ñ±ùëÅ{\cal F}^{(N)}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_N ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and build a (column normalized) matrix Œ¶Œ¶\Phiroman_Œ¶, such that if

k<m2‚Å¢(n‚àí1)+12,ùëòùëö2ùëõ112k<\frac{\sqrt{m}}{2(n-1)}+\frac{1}{2},italic_k < divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_m end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 ( italic_n - 1 ) end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , (6)

then Œ¶Œ¶\Phiroman_Œ¶ can be used to reconstruct kùëòkitalic_k-sparse signals via (P1(P_{1}( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). It is noted that (6) also greatly improves (5). The result in this paper can also be used to recover the sparse trigonometric polynomial with a single variable [27, 28].

In this paper, we also improve Katz‚Äô estimation for quadratic extension fields with an elementary and transparent approach. Using this improvement, we are able to construct a CS matrix which is a partial Fourier matrix, and whose columns are a union of orthonormal bases. This is a useful construction for sparse representation of signals in a union of orthonormal bases which has been a topic of some studies (see, for example [14, 15, 17, 18]). Moreover, this construction produces an approximately mutually unbiased bases which is of particular interest in quantum information theory. We also conduct some numerical experiments. The results show that the deterministic partial Fourier matrices has a better performance over the random partial Fourier matrices, provided that these two classes of matrices are of comparable sizes.

This paper is organized as follows. The section below provides some necessary concepts and results to be used in our discussion. The main results are given in section 3. The discussion of computational issues and numerical results are contained in the last section.

In [14], Donoho and Huo gave a computationally verifiable condition on the parameter Œºùúá\muitalic_Œº that ensures the sparse signal recovery: let Œ¶Œ¶\Phiroman_Œ¶ be a concatenation of two orthonormal matrices. Assume Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ is kùëòkitalic_k-sparse. If

This result of [14] was extended to a general matrix Œ¶Œ¶\Phiroman_Œ¶ by Fuchs [16], and, Gribonval and Nielsen [18], both in the noiseless case. The MIC Œºùúá\muitalic_Œº has been explicitly used in the design of compressed sensing matrices by several works, e.g., [3, 12, 2, 24, 37].

The method that Katz used in [20] to obtain the estimate (9) was a geometric one. In [25], Li presented an arithmetic proof of (9) using the Riemann hypothesis for the projective line over finite fields. It is interesting to note, in the case of quadratic extension of the fields, we can get a more precise estimation of Katz sum with an elementary and transparent proof. This result will be a useful tool in our construction of special CS matrices. Our improvement of Katz estimation is stated as

Remark 3.2

The concept of approximately mutually unbiased bases (AMUBs) (see [21, 22, 23]) arises from quantum information theory. An m√óNùëöùëÅm\times Nitalic_m √ó italic_N matrix Œ¶normal-Œ¶\Phiroman_Œ¶ (with columns of unit length and with m‚à£NconditionalùëöùëÅm\mid Nitalic_m ‚à£ italic_N) is a AMUBs if (i) the set of columns of Œ¶normal-Œ¶\Phiroman_Œ¶ can be partitioned into NmùëÅùëö\frac{N}{m}divide start_ARG italic_N end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG sets of mùëömitalic_m vectors, and each set is an orthonomal basis for ‚ÑÇmsuperscript‚ÑÇùëö{\mathbb{C}}^{m}blackboard_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; (ii) |‚ü®Œ¶k1,Œ¶k2‚ü©|=1m+o‚Å¢(1)subscriptnormal-Œ¶subscriptùëò1subscriptnormal-Œ¶subscriptùëò21ùëöùëú1\lvert\left<\Phi_{k_{1}},\Phi_{k_{2}}\right>\rvert=\sqrt{\frac{1}{m}}+o(1)| ‚ü® roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© | = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG end_ARG + italic_o ( 1 ) holds if Œ¶k1subscriptnormal-Œ¶subscriptùëò1\Phi_{k_{1}}roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ¶k2subscriptnormal-Œ¶subscriptùëò2\Phi_{k_{2}}roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are taken from different bases. By Taylor expansion, we have

q+1q+1=1q+1+O‚Å¢(1q+1),q‚àí1q+1=1q+1+O‚Å¢(1q+1).formulae-sequenceùëû1ùëû11ùëû1ùëÇ1ùëû1ùëû1ùëû11ùëû1ùëÇ1ùëû1\displaystyle\frac{\sqrt{q}+1}{q+1}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{q+1}}+O\left(\frac{1}{q+1}\right),\qquad\frac{\sqrt{q}-1}{q+1}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{q+1}}+O\left(\frac{1}{q+1}\right).divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_q end_ARG + 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_q + 1 end_ARG = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_q + 1 end_ARG end_ARG + italic_O ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_q + 1 end_ARG ) , divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_q end_ARG - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_q + 1 end_ARG = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_q + 1 end_ARG end_ARG + italic_O ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_q + 1 end_ARG ) .

So Theorem 3.3 says that we have actually constructed an AMUBs.

4 Computational Issues and Numerical Example

In this section we will first discuss the issues of finding a primitive root gùëîgitalic_g in ùîΩqnsubscriptùîΩsuperscriptùëûùëõ{\mathbb{F}}_{q^{n}}blackboard_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and of computing discrete logarithm with respect to gùëîgitalic_g. We then explain some results from our numerical experiments.

4.1 Computational Issues

Finding a primitive root of a finite field is an interesting problem. In [32], Shparlinski gave a deterministic algorithm which returns a primitive root gùëîgitalic_g of ùîΩqnsubscriptùîΩsuperscriptùëûùëõ{\mathbb{F}}_{q^{n}}blackboard_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in time O‚Å¢(qn4+Œµ)ùëÇsuperscriptùëûùëõ4ùúÄO(q^{\frac{n}{4}+\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG + italic_Œµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). It is noted that there is no polynomial time algorithm available for this problem even under the General Riemann Hypothesis unless qùëûqitalic_q is prime and n‚â§2ùëõ2n\leq 2italic_n ‚â§ 2 (see Shoup [31]). The idea of Shparlinski‚Äôs algorithm is to construct a subset M‚äÇùîΩqnùëÄsubscriptùîΩsuperscriptùëûùëõM\subset{\mathbb{F}}_{q^{n}}italic_M ‚äÇ blackboard_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that

  1. 1.

    MùëÄMitalic_M contains a primitive root;

  2. 2.

    |M|=O‚Å¢(qn4)ùëÄùëÇsuperscriptùëûùëõ4|M|=O(q^{\frac{n}{4}})| italic_M | = italic_O ( italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

To identify a primitive root in MùëÄMitalic_M one just uses the following fact: an element g‚ààùîΩqn‚àóùëîsuperscriptsubscriptùîΩsuperscriptùëûùëõ‚àóg\in{\mathbb{F}}_{q^{n}}^{\ast}italic_g ‚àà blackboard_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a primitive root if and only if gqn‚àí1‚Ñì‚â†‚Ñìsuperscriptùëîsuperscriptùëûùëõ1‚Ñì‚Ñìg^{\frac{q^{n}-1}{\ell}}\neq\ellitalic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_‚Ñì end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â† roman_‚Ñì for any prime factor ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ellroman_‚Ñì of qn‚àí1superscriptùëûùëõ1q^{n}-1italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1.

Computing a discrete logarithm over a finite field is also of great importance because the hardness of this problem is a base of several well-known cryptosystems. The index calculus methods provide efficient ways of solving discrete logarithm problem over finite fields (see [26]). However, since in our setting, the size of the finite field involved is far smaller than that in the cryptographical setting, we can use the following algorithm of Shanks [30] to compute the discrete logarithm in ùîΩqn‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùîΩsuperscriptùëûùëõ‚àó{\mathbb{F}}_{q^{n}}^{\ast}blackboard_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. 4.2 Numerical Examples

The purpose of the experiments is to provide some performance comparisons of the random sampling and the deterministic sampling of Fourier matrices. We use the method introduced in this paper to produce a deterministic partial Fourier matrix. To compare with the deterministic partial Fourier matrix, we generate the random partial Fourier matrix by choosing the same number of rows (as that in the deterministic case) from the Fourier matrix in a uniformly random manner. We reconstruct the Fourier coefficients by OMP (see [27, 36]) and BP, respectively. For BP, we use the optimization tools of CVX [7]. We repeat the experiment 100 times for each sparsity k‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,20}ùëò1‚Ä¶20k\in\{1,\ldots,20\}italic_k ‚àà { 1 , ‚Ä¶ , 20 } and calculate the success rate in Example 1 and Example 2. In Example 3, we compare the maximum and minimum eigenvalue statistics of Gram matrices Œ¶T‚ä§‚Å¢Œ¶TsuperscriptsubscriptŒ¶ùëátopsubscriptŒ¶ùëá\Phi_{T}^{\top}\Phi_{T}roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of varying sparsity k=|T|ùëòùëák=|T|italic_k = | italic_T | for a deterministic sampling matrix and a random sampling matrix. It is interesting to note that all the numerical results show that the deterministic partial Fourier matrix has a better performance over the random partial Fourier matrix, regardless whether the sparsity if within the theoretical range (i.e. k<12‚Å¢(1Œº+1)ùëò121ùúá1k<\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{\mu}+1\right)italic_k < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG + 1 )) or not.
